awd_titl_txt: Magnetic microrollers as a platform for active transport
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET - 1706562
PI: Donev, Aleksandar

Suspensions of particles in a viscous liquid often exhibit unusual behavior in flow.  This award will study suspensions of magnetic particles that rotate in an applied magnetic field.  The rotation of the particles induces a flow in the surrounding liquid.  The investigators have found that an instability in the suspension leads to the formations of loosely-packed aggregates of the particles, which can move away from the rest of the suspension under guidance from the magnetic field.  The aggregates stay intact as they move, even though the particles inside an aggregate do not touch each other.  This leads to an interesting new way to transport particles through a liquid that could be applied in microfluidic or lab-on-a-chip systems where the small dimensions of the device often limit transport of particulate phases.  This award will support experimental studies to study the generation of the aggregates, their motion, and the interactions of the aggregates with obstacles they encounter in the flow.  The experiments will be complemented by numerical studies that will help interpret data and explore the mechanisms of aggregate formation and motion.

A model system of magnetic microllers near a wall will be used to explore a new platform for active transport.  Numerical simulations will be used to identify conditions under which microroller aggregates are expected to form.  Experiments will validate the formation of the aggregates and demonstrate effects of different particle shape on aggregation formation and transport.  To simulate flow in a structured environment, microroller transport will be studied in an array of patterned posts in periodic, quasi-periodic, self-similar and disordered patterns.  The potential for using the microroller system for transporting colloidal cargos will be investigated.  The experiments and simulations of the microroller system form visually appealing demonstrations that will be used in hands on activities for elementary and high school students in the New York area.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on the development of a novel platform for flow generation and particle transport at the microscale. The system we studied is a suspension of colloidal (micrometer-sized) particles that are spun by an applied rotating magnetic field. Prior work by the research team discovered that in confined spaces such active suspensions of microrollers can form autonomous, persistent, guidable, and motile clusters termed critters. Such critters can potentially be used to transport cargo at the microscale in engineering and medical applications, provided that their formation, stability, and interaction with obstacles is understood.

Our team combined experiments, theory, and computer simulations to study the behavior of colloids driven externally using gravitational forces, electric fields, and rotating magnetic fields. We have elucidated mathematically, computationally, and experimentally the nontrivial collective dynamics of such suspensions. We have also performed some of the most careful experimental measurements in the field, and demonstrated excellent quantitative agreement between experiments and theoretical/computational predictions.

This research has led to several significant scientific findings. PIs Donev and Co-PI Driscoll have shown using both simulations and experiments that at sufficiently high densities a uniform suspension of microrollers separates into two layers, a slow monolayer right above the wall, and a fast layer on top of the bottom layer. Co-PI Delmotte found that stable bound states could be formed with only two microrollers when gravity was present. He identified the key dimensionless number that controls the formation of bound states, and completely characterized the phase space for a pair of rollers. Co-PIs Driscoll and Delmotte have shown using simulations, experiments, and theory that obstacles can trap microroller particles using a hydrodynamic mechanism.

More then a dozen undergraduate and graduate students and several postdoctoral researchers were mentored and trained, and the work has led to several publications in leading journals in the field of soft condensed matter physics. We have developed public domain computer codes for simulating confined active colloidal suspensions.


Last Modified: 11/05/2021
Modified by: Aleksandar Donev

Image
  • The distribution of velocities in the direction of collective motion for a microroller suspension (experimental versus simulation results). The inset shows a typical two-lane configuration for a uniform suspension; low (slow) particles are magenta while high (fast) particles are yellow.
    "Driven dynamics in dense suspensions of microrollers" by B. Sprinkle, E. B. van der Wee and Y. Luo and M. Driscoll, and A. Donev, Soft Matter, 16, 7982 - 8001, 2020.
    Copyrighted
    Aleksandar Donev
    Bulk suspension of microrollers
